TextView.android:text: There are a large number of house/tournament rules in Riichi Mahjong. Many rules are changed/added/omitted from various tournaments and leagues; this will explain the core aspects of the scoring process. In the future I may add a guide/list of the more commmon local rule changes used.

The game begins with each player in possession of 25000 points, in the form of sticks of value: 1x 10,000, 2x 5,000, 4x 1,000, and 10x 100. Sometimes 5 of the 100 point sticks will be replaced with a single 500 point stick.

When a player declares a win (either via Tsumo or Ron), if the hand does not contain a valid yaku when revealed the hand is declared invalid. The owner of the hand must pay a Chombo penalty payment to the other players and a new hand is played as though that hand never happened (any Riichi sticks are returned, etc).

In order to win a hand, a player must win either by drawing the winning tile themselves on their turn (Tsumo/Self-Draw) or complete their hand with a tile another player discards (Ron/Win via Discard); additionally, the hand must include at least one Yaku (see Yaku Descriptions for a list). In general, this means the hand will consist of a pair of tiles and four Melds of three tiles. A Meld can be either three in a row of the same non-honors suit, or three copies of the same tile.

The number of han (飜) in a hand is the sum of all the yaku (役; win conditions) and dora (ドラ; bonus tiles) in the hand. A winning hand must include at least one yaku, regardless of the number of dora present. If there is more than one way to arrange the winning hand (such as a hand that qualifies for both ryanpeikou (二盃口) and chītoitsu (七対子)), the arrangement with the highest Han is used.

A list of all yaku can be found under the 'Yaku Descriptions' main menu option. BEGINNER'S NOTE: It is not important to memorize all of these to learn the basics of scoring! On the 'Yaku Descriptions' page, if you select 'Han sorted by Frequency' in the dropdown at the top, you will see that only a handful of yaku make up the vast majority of winning hands. The first ones to learn and get comfortable with include: Riichi, Tanyao, Pinfu, Tsumo, Honitsu and Yakuhai.
If the number of han in the hand adds up to 5 or more, skip the next step and go straight to '4) Find the value of the hand'.
A winning hand is automatically awarded a base of 20 fu (副底; fūtei).
Ten fu are added if one wins by claiming a discarded tile with a closed hand (門前加符; menzen-kafu).

Add fu for the melds and the pair (see table below for clarification). A sequential Meld provides 0 Fu. Melds with multiples of the same tile however start with a base Fu value of 2 and are doubled if the meld is closed, doubled if the tile is an Honor or Terminal, and quadrupled if the Meld consists of four of the same tile. 2 Fu are awarded to the pair if they are the Seat Wind, Prevailing Wind, or are dragons (4 Fu are awarded if they qualify for both winds).
Add fu according to the wait (see table below for clarification). 2 fu are awarded for single-sided or inside waits on a sequential Meld, or if the winning tile completes the pair.
Add two fu if the winning tile was self-drawn (自摸/ツモ; tsumo). One exception is if the hand includes a yaku of pinfu (平和; no-points hand), in which case the hand is counted as a total of 20 fu.
Another exception is winning with a yaku of chītoitsu and is counted as 25 fu.
The final exception is if one wins by claiming a discard with an open pinfu hand and is counted as 30 fu.
(4 fu if tiles are both winds)
(fu is still counted as normal for the meld)
4) Find the value of the hand

There are four pieces of information needed to determine the value of the hand: Han, Fu, Dealer/Non-Dealer, Ron/Tsumo. The math involved here isn't particularly difficult, but it can take a bit of time to do the math, and as not everyone is comfortable doing the math in their head I will provide a few different strategies to determine the final value of the hand from these four pieces of information.

An important thing to note is that the value of a hand doubles for each Han, until the hand reaches a base value of 8000 points, at which point the Fu no longer matters and the base value of the hand increases according to the following table:
* A hand with 3 or 4 Han may become a Mangan with enough Fu. To become a Mangan a 3 Han hand requires 70+ Fu, while a 4 Han hand requires 40+ Fu.

Most players do not do the math to determine the size of their hand in the middle of a game, rather they rely on one of the methods listed below. Still, it is important to at least be aware of how the math works to truly understand the scoring system.

The number of points each player must pay depends on two factors: Did the winning player self-draw (自摸, or ツモ; tsumo) the winning tile themselves or did they win off of a discard (栄 or ロン; ron)? Was the winning player the dealer (親; oya; parent) or a non-dealer (子; ko; child)?

If the winner wins via self-draw all the other players must pay a portion of the points. If the winner wins via a discarded tile ONLY the player who discarded the tile pays; this is a rule to encourage players to play defensively and pay attention to the other players at the table, and discourage discarding tiles that another player may win with.
Being the dealer is a high-risk/high-reward position to be in; a dealer risks paying more points if another player wins via self-draw, but is rewarded with +50% points for any hands won while dealer.

Round the portions from the previous step up to the nearest 100. NOTE: The base points are the same for a Ron and a Tsumo, but the number of points actually exchanged may be slightly different due to this rounding.

This is the preferred method of beginner and intermediate players. Depending on your preference, there are two ways to lookup the value of the hand. From the Main Menu you can select either 'Score Table' for a series of static tables, which are excellent to get a general grasp of the kinds of scores of various sized hands, and the 'Han/Fu' calculator, which will let you enter the relavent pieces of information and get your response quickly.

This is the method that most experienced players utilize. As you get more experienced in Riichi Mahjong you will notice a lot of patterns and that the same numbers keep coming up. By memorizing only a handful of numbers, you can easily extrapolate and determine the value of the vast majority of hands. Interesting things to note:
The vast majority of hands have 20/30/40 Fu or are a hand with a fixed value, such as a Mangan

Doubling the Fu and increasing the Han by one both double the value of the hand. This means that a 2 Han 20 Fu hand is the same value as a 1 Han 40 Fu hand. It also means that a 1 Han 60 Fu hand is the same as a 2 Han 30 Fu hand, so if you memorize the more common lower Fu hands, you also know a lot of the higher Fu hands.

The math/rounding always leads to the same numbers coming up, for example a 1 Han 30 Fu hand is 1000 points, double that is 2000 points, double that is 3900 points, double that is 7700 points. There are no non-capped hands (such as a Mangan) that are worth 4000 points, but there MANY hands with 3900. Glance at the "Score Table" and you will see that around 10 numbers account for the vast majority of the entries.

You don't need to memorize any of the values associated with dealer wins, as their values are always 50% larger than the non-dealer value. For a Tsumo, it is the same as a non-dealer Tsumo except that all players pay the larger number; for a Ron, rounding can make this a little trickier (what is 2000 + 50%? 2900 of course!) but is still fairly straightforward.

Each time a winning hand is declared, the winner receives a bonus 300 points for each continuance counter (honba; 本場) currently present in the middle of the table and the count is then reeset to zero. Honba are a counter for the number of dealer wins/draws in a row.

The current delear should place one 100 point stick in the middle for each Honba; these point sticks still belong to the player, if dealership passes for any reason or the count is reset, the player should take their sticks back and the new dealer will replace them. Honba count is increased if:
The dealer wins a hand (dealership does not pass)
An abortive draw is declared (dealership does not pass)
The hand is a draw (ryūkyoku; 流局) (dealership is passed if the dealer cannot declare tenpai)
Each paying player pays an equal share of this bonus (for a Ron, the discarding player pays all 300 points per counter; for a Tsumo, each player pays 100 points per counter).
A commonly used rule called ryanhan-shibari (two-han binding; 二飜縛り) requires any winning hand to contain at least two han from yaku if the Honba count is five or greater.

After the game is finished, the points of each of the three players other than the winner is rounded off to the nearest 1,000. The winner's points are the difference between 120,000 (30,000 × 4) and the total of these three players' points. The number of points is divided by 1,000, and 30 is finally subtracted from it. The sum of these final points is always zero. In most cases there are additional points transferred based on the players' final places (uma). (For example: 1st gets +20, 2nd gets +10, 3rd gets -10 and 4th gets -20)
